rows.name: spacer
rows.value: Problem Solving Overview

rows.name: help_text
rows.value:
During these earliest years, lots of interesting problem solving can occur. It is important that you lay the foundation for good lifelong attitudes and habits for your students towards problem solving and math.

There are three aspects of problem solving to pay attention to. While it is tempting to focus your attention on Strategies, they are useless in the absence of good Attitudes and Self Monitoring.

Once the first three aspects are in place, the last aspect to understand is the Process of Problem Solving. Much of this, such as the self monitoring, is a bit sophisticated for a young child. However, you should be aware of all four parts so you can introduce them to your students as they become ready for them.

rows.name: accord_attitudes
rows.value: Attitudes and Beliefs

rows.name: temp_text_a
rows.value:
A person's attitudes and beliefs about math have a strong influence on how successful they will be as a problem solver.

One of your most important tasks as a math teacher is to create a classroom culture that promotes good attitudes. Creating this culture will take time, and it requires patience and persistence on your part.

Here are a list of positive attitudes to promote and nuture:
* Math is fun, playful, and social.
* Math can require effort and be challenging – and still be fun and fulfilling.
* It's good to take appropriate risks. Mistakes and failures are an important part of the process. Highlight your own mistakes when they occur.
* Students should respectuflly challenge the ideas of others (and gracefully accept those challenges), and listen to and build on the ideas of others.
* Having a partial solution is useful.
* Persistence and grit are powerful attributes. Putting a problem aside and coming back to it later can lead to fresh insights.
* Everyone can see themselves as a math person.
* The current puzzle can be a stepping stone in an exciting journey in related puzzles the students discover and explore.

You will be fighting against a very large collection of negative misconceptions:
* People are either born with math talent or they are not.
* I am a weak math student, so my ideas are generally useless.
* Math work is lonely.
* I will never use this math in my real life.
* Only geniuses are capable of discovering or creating mathematics. 
* If I can't solve a problem in 2 minutes, it must require an expert.
* Immediately after reading a problem statement, I should understand what is asked.
* Attaining the answer is the most important aspect of problem solving.
* Accept procedures at face value and don't try to understand why they work.
* The math I learn in school is mostly facts and procedures that have to be memorized.
* It's okay to use math that you do not understand as long as you know how to use it.
* There is always a rule to follow in solving math problems.
* Math problems have one and only one right answer, and only one way to get it.

rows.name: accord_time
rows.value: Self Monitoring

rows.name: temp_text_b
rows.value:
Here are three questions you can ask your students when they are problem solving to help focus their work:
* What exactly are you doing? Can you describe it precisely?
* Why are you doing what you are doing? How does it fit into your vision of the solution?
* How does it help you? What will you do with the outcome of this work when you obtain it?

Here are some questions a problem solver should ask themselves on a regular basis:
* Should I pursue this line of thought further, or should I put it aside for now and consider an alternative approach?
* Should I take this opportunity to create a list of possible next steps by applying some problem-solving strategies?
* How do I rank the possible next steps I have generated? Generally speaking, quicker steps would rank higher because they can be dispensed with quickly. Complex calculations should generally be avoided unless no simpler options are available. However; a particularly promising long calculation might be preferred if confidence in it is high.
* Is it time to take a break and let my thoughts regroup in the background?

rows.name: accord_strategies
rows.value: Problem Solving Strategies

rows.name: intro_strategies_text
rows.value: There are many problem solving strategies. Among those are a few general strategies that will serve you and your students well in a great many circumstances. Early introduction and repeated explicitly exposure will build these into lifelong tools for your students.

rows.name: accord_strategies_1
rows.value: 1. Do examples and simpler problem versions

rows.name: example_text_for_strategy_1a
rows.value:
**Overview:** Doing lots of examples and variations can open your eyes to things easily missed in the original problem. One example is often not enough to see the mechanisms at play in a puzzle. It’s too easy to get distracted by unimportant details in that particular situation. By looking at many examples, patterns emerge and common characteristics that are crucial start to stand out.

A fun aspect of playing with examples and variations is that they may lead you to ask new questions to explore.

**Do many examples and look for patterns:**

**Example – Bridges of Königsberg:** The challenge in this puzzle is to find a parade route that will travel exactly once across each of the seven bridges in this diagram. A little experimentation will quickly convince you that it is impossible, but how do you understand and prove it?

rows.name: bridges_of_k_illustration
rows.value: ESMIll/ESMBridgesOfKonigsbergChallenge.svg

rows.name: example_text_for_strategy_1b
rows.value: For this puzzle, there are many simpler diagrams that one can play with, some of which are illustrated above. After playing with those, and perhaps others, a pattern emerges. Any node that has an odd number of sides attached to it must be the beginning or ending of a path. That is the key insight which leads to a complete understanding of these parade puzzles.

rows.name: parades_illustration
rows.value: ESMIll/ESMParades1.svg

rows.name: example_text_for_strategy_1c
rows.value:
**Do simipler versions of the problem and look for patterns:**

**Example - Nim:** Suppose you have ten things and you and your opponent are allowed to remove 1 or 2 things from the pile on each turn. The player who removes the last piece wins. Is it better to go first or second, and what is your strategy?

Ten is too big a number for seeing the strategy, so let’s reduce it to create simpler versions of the problem. When I asked my high school seniors to do this, they would choose numbers like 3 or 5. If it provides information, always start with the simplest version (1 in this case) and work your way up. Write down what happens if it’s your turn and there are 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5 things in a pile. In a few seconds  the pattern emerges and you have conquered this game.

rows.name: accord_strategies_2
rows.value: 2. Organize data in lists, tables, and graphs

rows.name: example_text_for_strategy_2
rows.value: Give examples.

rows.name: accord_strategies_3
rows.value: 3. Do intelligent Guess-and-Check

Some consider Guess and Check as something an unintelligent person does when they have no ideas. That attitude needlessly wastes the use of a very powerful strategy.

**Puzzle:** Suppose a farmer has a total of 200 chickens and cows. Weirdly, the farmer counts the legs and notices there are 680 legs. How many of each animal are there?

If there were 200 cows, there would be 800 legs, and if there were 200 chickens, there would be 400 legs. Let’s guess 100 of each animal. That would give 600 legs. To get more legs, we need more cows. Let’s guess 150 cows – this gives 700 legs. Reduce the cows to 140 and you get exactly 680 legs. 

The thoughtful person using Guess and Check here would notice that the number of legs increases by twice as much as the increase in the number of cows, and would then use that information to improve future trial numbers. If you are watching and thinking as you do Guess and Check, it has many of the strengths of using the lots of examples strategy.
rows.name: text_1
accord_strategies_4
rows.value: 4. Represent problem in a more relatable way

rows.name: example_text_for_strategy_4
rows.value:
This can be done in many ways. The most common is to organize the given information into a list, table, or graph. Sometimes it takes the form of an annotated drawing the captures the puzzle information and also conveys the activities in the puzzle. A less common form is to act out the problem in some physical way using objects or people.

For example, there are several puzzles involving flipping over coins. To get a better understanding of this puzzle, you might set up a collection of coins and watch what happens when you flip the coins.

Suppose you have a problem such as: You are given two apples, then you are given 4 more apples. When some apples are taken away you are left with 3 apples. How many apples were taken away. For a student struggling to understand the problem, they can use some collection of small objects and act out the actions in the problem.

If the problem involves collecting apples from two places and then leaving some at a friends house, it may be helpful to draw a simple diagram with counts of apples at each location.

rows.name: accord_strategies_5
rows.value: 5. Find a related problem you know how to solve

rows.name: example_text_for_strategy_5
rows.value:
Sometimes one problem uses structures or rules that are similar to a problem you have already figured out. In that case, we can use our understand of the old problem to save work with the new one.

**Example: Nim with Addition:** Suppose you want to understand the version of Nim where you start at 0, add one or two things each time, and the person who brings the total number of things to ten wins.

This is just like the subtraction version of Nim described earlier, which we’ve already analyzed. If you think of the ten things sitting off to the side ready to be added to the pile, each time you add one or two to the adding pile you are removing one or two from the pile of ten – the adding pile will reach ten exactly when the subtracting pile reaches zero!

rows.name: accord_strategies_6
rows.value: 6. Find extreme parts of the problem

rows.name: example_text_for_strategy_6a
rows.value: Extreme parts often dictate what happens in the rest of the problem and are often easier starting points.

rows.name: sum_groups_illustratioin
rows.value: ESMIll/ESMSumGroups10.svg

rows.name: example_text_for_strategy_6b
rows.value: The challenge here is to find pairs and triplets of connecting squares that add up to 10, and to fill the whole square with such groups. What are the extreme points here? The smallest and largest numbers are very restricted in how they can match, so those are good places to start. Also, the corners (and to a lesser extent the edges) are restricted. Once you’ve determined what happens with the 1s, 2s, 8s, and 9s, the rest of this puzzle goes very quickly.

rows.name: accord_strategies_7
rows.value: 7. Work forward from givens and backward from goals

rows.name: example_text_for_strategy_7a
rows.value:
This strategy is particularly effective in many geometry proofs, but those problems are more advanced than the material in this app.

**Puzzle – Treasure Hunt:** Even for a puzzle as small as this, there can be many choices to consider if we only start at the beginning and go forward. Save work by combining going forward with going backward from the goal.

rows.name: treasure_hunt_puzzle
rows.value: ESMIll/ESMTreasureMap2.svg

rows.name: example_text_for_strategy_7b
rows.value:
Going forward from the Start we can go to either the upper right corner or the lower left corner. From those corners there are four places to consider, which begins to be a lot.

Which squares can end at the $$ goal square? There is only one square that can land there, which is the “1” in the square next to the $$. Continuing, there is only one square that can reach that “1,” and that is the “2” two squares above the "1." It will not be long before this backtracking reaches one of the four going-forward possibilities found earlier, and then you are done.

rows.name: accord_process
rows.value: Process of Problem Solving

rows.name: temp_text_d
rows.value:
1. **Understand the problem deeply.** Read the problem carefully and make sure you understand all the terms and the assumptions built into the problem. Look for similar problems you've seen in the past. Look for a good way to present the information of the problem (e.g. tables, drawing).
2. **Search for and pursue strategies.** This is where most of the time will be spent.
- a. Analyze the problem looking for entry points and strategies. Make a list (at least mentally) of your strategies and rank them by probable usefulness.
- b. Pick your top ranked strategy and pursue it. Monitor the time you spend on it and whether pursuing it continues to make sense. When it stops making sense, go on to step c.
- c. Select a new strategy. Do this either by choosing the next strategy on your list, or by going back to step (1) and check for things you may have misunderstood or missed.
3. **Review your solution.** Check that your solution is correct and that it makes sense in the world of the problem (for example, deciding that you need 2 2/3 cars would not make sense). Write out all the steps in your solution as clearly as you can. Compare it to other problems you have worked on. Look for new directions you can take the ideas of this problem to explore more math puzzles.
